text:
```julia> v[1] isa eltype(v)
false```
That's... interesting. This is a custom array type with just one non-zero element of type T. I store the element value, index and the vector size only. The thing above happens when calling it with an irrational
`v = MaybeHotVector(π, 2, 33)`
Ok that comes from `zero(Irrational) = false`   which is not an `Irrational`

text:
Interesting :smile:

This creates some issues elsewhere
```julia> zeros(Irrational, 1, 2)
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching Irrational(::Bool)
Closest candidates are:
  Irrational(::T) where T<:Number at boot.jl:716
  Irrational(::Complex) where T<:Real at complex.jl:37
  Irrational(::Base.TwicePrecision) where T<:Number at twiceprecision.jl:243
  ...
Stacktrace:
 [1] convert(::Type{Irrational}, ::Bool) at ./number.jl:7
 [2] fill!(::Array{Irrational,2}, ::Bool) at ./array.jl:355
 [3] zeros(::Type{Irrational}, ::Tuple{Int64,Int64}) at ./array.jl:526
 [4] zeros(::Type{Irrational}, ::Int64, ::Int64) at ./array.jl:521
 [5] top-level scope at REPL[11]:1```

text: This is a weird one because it makes sense not to be able to create an irrational 0, but at the same time it results in a numeric type with "holes"
